lines.text: If you read my statement carefully, you'll note that I left myself a loophole. A course I recommend to any man who dedicates his life to living off the taxpayer.
Morely! What are *you* doing here?
[Morely closes and latches the bedroom door]
What do you want?
Come on. You don't have to put on no act for me. You knew I'd be around.
Get out of here, or I'll phone the police.
[Rushes to pick up the telephone. Morely grabs her, hangs up the phone, and handles her roughly]
Who are you trying to kid?
As a politician of sorts, I know when to withdraw.
Did Eisenhower have an organization? Senator, this is the age of celebrity. In entertainment, business, politics. Celebrities write their own ticket. You don't need a machine anymore.
Judges don't have the same privileges as Senators and District Attorneys. We have to resign before we seek another office.
It's you Alex! The things you've let me see in you!

Whatever I've done, I've done for you! Do I have to tell you that? I'm trying to lift you to the dizziest heights there are in this world! To make you the First Lady of this... uhhhh... ugggggghhhhh...
[collapses]
He is sure of my loyalty. He is trying to win my love.
Has Miss Laura Mayberry been under surveillance for the last three days?
Yes.
Why?
Because you asked me to do it.
Walter! Walter!
Laura, is it true?
[Laura doesn't answer]
Is it?
[Still no answer]
Well, tell me!
Walter, I...
Don't do it, Laura. No matter what happens to me, *don't do it!*
Your Honor, the crudeness of this scheme shocks me. There was nothing in that room to indicate the commission of any crime, and yet this witness...
There was plenty!
Plenty? A moment ago you said you had only a hunch!
Yeah, I had more than that. Thornwall tried to kill his wife once before, and she called the police!
Mistrial! Your Honor, I move for a mistrial! His is the most damaging piece of viciously prejudicial evidence I have ever heard in any courtroom!
There's no ground for a mistrial! If he didn't want the answer, he shouldn't have asked the question!
Order!
[Bangs gavel]
Order!
[Bangs gavel again]
I'm going to clear this room if we don't have order.
I may have overruled a good mistrial motion, just to show Alex that he couldn't buy me.
I think Alex had already discovered that.
Yes, well I guess I was just trying to prove it to myself.
Or maybe there's an element of masochism that goes along with honor.
Thanks for that word 'honor,' Cathy. 'Vanity' might be more accurate.

I'm only allowed a minute. So I will try to change the habit of a lifetime, and be brief. I wanted you to hear this, Lee. Itchy, tell the reporters that what Judge Hoffman said about me, and the mistrial motion, was true - from his point of view.
Thank you, Alex.

Politicians aren't perfect, Lee. Any more than the people they serve. If they were, it wouldn't be democracy; it would be something else. Sometimes we even have to play a little dirty for the ultimate good. That's why I want all the boys to get behind Callahan. He knows the rules of the game, and he can win. Do you hear me, Itchy?
You don't want me to repeat any of this, Alex. Because you're going to be OK.
If I could be sure of that, I'd keep my big mouth shut. Now get out of here before you break my heart.
You were formerly Governor of this State?
Yes.
What is your relation to the defendant?
Walter Thornwall is my nephew.
When was the last time you saw his wife?
I saw Paula on the eighth of February.
Two days before she met her death.
Since that was the last time I saw her alive, I can hardly forget the time or the occasion.
And what was the occasion, Governor?
Dinner in my home.
Aside from you and Paula Thornwall, who else was present?
My nephew Walter. I wanted to try to bring them back together.
And what was the result?
I failed.
From the way they behaved towards one another during the time you were with them, would you say that...
Objection. Leading the witness.
Sustained.
I'll rephrase that. What was their attitude toward one another during the evening?
They behaved like two people who understood each other.

I'm not trying to flatter you. I may even insult you a little. You're shanty-Irish, born in the slum, raised on charity, educated on the GI Bill. In other words you're exactly the balance Lee needs. You know, out here it's pretty hard to live down Groton and Harvard, even if you try - and Lee doesn't. Besides, you've both got youth, the thing they make a fetish out of here in America. Of course, I prefer the European attitude, where even the women place a premium on age. But then, this isn't Europe.

Well, Dan, you win. Being Governor of this State, beating you, they aren't worth a damn if I have to turn myself into another Dan Callahan to get them. For one minute, sitting up there, I felt like a total stranger to my own self. I don't have to tell you what a sick sensation that is.
My conscience doesn't hurt.
Oh? Well, maybe you've gotten used to it by now.
Mr. Miller, I understand that, among other things, you tap telephones.
Now wait a minute, Judge! There's nothing illegal about that in this State. It's what you do with it that might break the law.
I'm aware of that. I want you to tap one for me.
Oh, now, why didn't you say that in the first place?
One picture worth ten thousand votes.
